content: The "Safety of Seniors Act of 2008" amends the Public Health Service Act to include a section on the prevention of falls among older adults. The "Safety of Seniors Act of 2008" amends the Public Health Service Act to include a section on the prevention of falls among older adults. The Secretary may oversee a national education campaign and award grants for fall prevention programs. The Secretary may conduct research to improve identification of older adults at high risk of falling, enhance data collection for fall risk factors, evaluate effective prevention interventions, and tailor strategies for specific populations. The Secretary conducts research to maximize dissemination of effective fall prevention interventions, intensify interventions for older adults, improve diagnosis and treatment of fall victims, assess fall risks in different settings, study barriers to intervention adoption, and develop new prevention strategies. The Secretary conducts research to develop and evaluate effective approaches to reducing falls among high-risk older adults in communities and care facilities. They also evaluate community programs designed to prevent falls among older adults and provide professional education in fall prevention for healthcare professionals and aging service providers. The Secretary may oversee and support demonstration projects specializing in falls or fall prevention, including multistate projects for targeted fall risk screening and referral programs, and programs for older adults with multicomponent intervention approaches. The Secretary may award grants to organizations specializing in falls prevention to design and implement programs for older adults at high risk for falls. Private sector partnerships are encouraged to develop technologies for fall prevention and injury reduction. The Secretary may award grants to organizations specializing in falls prevention to design, implement, and evaluate fall prevention programs using proven intervention strategies in residential and institutional settings. This includes identifying high-risk populations, evaluating residential facilities, and conducting screening to identify high-risk individuals. The Secretary may award grants to organizations specializing in falls prevention to conduct evaluations of fall prevention programs. Priority may be given to entities exploring cost-sharing options. The Secretary may award grants to organizations specializing in falls prevention to conduct evaluations of fall prevention programs, with priority given to entities exploring cost-sharing options. Additionally, the Secretary may conduct a review of the effects of falls on health care costs and strategies for reducing associated costs. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 36 months of the Safety of Seniors Act of 2008 enactment, detailing the findings of the review conducted.
